text:
I was not planning to do
a startup while at HBS.
Please welcome Team Confi.

I'm Tess an I'm the
founder of Confi.

Confi is a free online platform
for young women seeking advice

on sensitive topics, like
gynecology questions,

sexual health,
and mental health.

I've always been passionate
about women's empowerment.

But I wasn't sure how I could
apply that to a business.

Having that first semester--
seeing students around me

during business-- helped
give me the confidence
that I could actually do this.

Confi's mission is
to empower women
to be confident in themselves.

It was only in
March of first year

that I actually came up with the
idea and decided to pursue it.

There are so many resources
for student entrepreneurs.

We've been involved in the
New Venture Competition

and got second place,
which is amazing.

The Rock Accelerator
program, and we work out
of the Innovation Lab.

We have seen great
traction since we
joined the Rock Accelerator.

The New Venture
Competition was great,

because it made us articulate
clearly what our plans are
for the next three years.

How are we going to
measure social impact?

We had to articulate who
are all of our competitors
and our greatest risks?

And present that in front
of a panel of expert judges

who had very critical
questions and made us challenge
some of our assumptions.

Why are we a for-profit,
not a non-profit?

How will we deal with
conflict of interest
for corporate sponsors?

Our business model is low
cost and very scalable,

and we have three
main revenue streams.

My second year class experience
has been very different

than my first year
class experience
because of doing a startup.

It used to feel a
little more abstract

talking about these
CEOs'  business problems.

And now you can directly
apply it to your startup.

So in managing human
capital, we were talking
about how to hire people.

And at the same week, I
was interviewing interns

and thinking about
how can I apply this?

We create all of the
content ourselves

and make the information
more engaging and relatable.

Doctors validate
all of our content.
I'm now working with 14 people.

It started just
with me a year ago.

Seeing them develop and
seeing the team evolve
has been rewarding.

Every entrepreneur
has those days

where you doubt--
can I really do this?

I don't know anyone
who's regretted

worked in a startup while at
HBS, even those that failed quickly.

I think the hardest
part is actually

doing it-- building
something new that

helps people has been such a
meaningful experience for me.

And it's something that
I plan to be involved in
the rest of my life.

It has been such a defining
part of my HBS experience

that I am so grateful
that I've had
this opportunity to pursue it.
